translated: The Dharma and Etiquette of the Ten Precepts for Novice Monks in One Fascicle

The Buddha said to ÅšÄriputra, Go and ordain RÄhula. ÅšÄriputra said:
How should I ordain him?
The Buddha instructed him, saying:
I, RÄhula, take refuge in the Buddha, take refuge in the Dharma, take refuge in the Saá¹…gha.
Thus, I, so-and-so, have taken refuge in the Buddha, have taken refuge in the Dharma, have taken refuge in the Saá¹…gha.

For as long as I live, I will refrain from killing, for as long as I live, I will refrain from stealing, for as long as I live, I will refrain from sexual misconduct, for as long as I live, I will refrain from false speech, for as long as I live, I will refrain from drinking alcohol. The Buddha, the BhagavÄn, has gone forth. I, so-and-so, following my preceptor so-and-so, have gone forth following the Buddha.
Thus, I, so-and-so, following my preceptor so-and-so, have gone forth following the Buddha, have abandoned lay clothing and put on the dyed robe.
For the rest of your life, do not kill, uphold the novice precepts.ğŸ”½ For the rest of your life, do not steal, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not engage in sexual misconduct, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not lie, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not drink alcohol, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not wear flower garlands, perfume, or adorn the body, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not sing, dance, play music, or go watch and listen, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not sit on high, wide, and large beds, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not eat at improper times, uphold the novice precepts.
For the rest of your life, do not handle gold, silver, or precious objects that resemble them, uphold the novice precepts.
You have now received the ten novice precepts. For the rest of your life, you must uphold them with utmost respect and never violate them.
You should make offerings to the Three Jewels, and to your preceptor and teacher, and not go against any of the Dharma teachings.
Whether with superiors, equals, or inferiors, always be respectful.
Strive to find the means to sit in meditation, recite sutras, study, and encourage the making of merit, closing the three evil paths and opening the gate to nirvana.
In the Dharma of the monks, increase the right practices and attain the fruits of the four paths.
The precepts of the novice monk are that for as long as you live, you should not harm or injure people or living beings.
You should remember the kindness of your parents, teachers, and friends, and diligently practice the path in order to deliver your parents.
Be careful not to be angry or litigious, give credit to others, and take the blame upon yourself.
Do not harm any crawling, flying, or slithering creatures, but bestow kindness and aid those in need, allowing them to find peace.
Think of others in your heart, and do not speak of killing. If you see killing, do not eat; if you hear the sound of killing, do not eat; if you suspect killing, do not eat.
When seeing killing, one should give rise to a compassionate mind and vow, 'When I attain the Way, there will be no killing in my country.'
Do not use plants and trees, and be careful not to damage them.
If one violates this precept, one is not a novice monk.

The precepts of a novice monk are that for one's whole life one must not steal.ğŸ”½Do not deceive others even by a hair's breadth or a grain of rice, keep one's mind in righteousness and do not instruct others to take what is not given.
Do not buy or sell servants, slaves, or hired workers, or accept gifts from them.
Do not wear luxurious clothes or use high beds or canopies, but dress simply to cover one's body without adornment.
Eat just enough to sustain life, and do not indulge in delicacies.
Do not store grain or accumulate filthy treasures. Do not accept gifts from others, and if accepted, do not keep them but give them to the poor.
Always teach others the virtue of non-greed, and would rather have one's hand cut off than take what is not given.
If one violates this precept, one is not a novice monk.
The precepts of a novice monk are to not take a wife or raise heirs for the duration of one's life.
Avoid women, restrain the six senses, and do not look at beautiful colors.
Do not gaze with the eyes, do not think of lust in the mind, and do not speak lewd words with the mouth.
Do not use flowers, incense, grease, or powder to adorn the body, and do not look at or listen to seductive sounds or sights.
Rather than breaking bones, crushing the heart, or burning the body, do not engage in sexual activity.
Even if born from lust and impurity, it is not as good as dying chaste.
If one violates this precept, one is not a novice monk.
The precepts of a novice monk are to be sincere and faithful for the duration of one's life. Do not engage in slander, abusive language, false speech, or frivolous talk.

Do not praise in front and slander behind, or use testimony to incriminate others. Speak slowly and hold to the principles, do not expose others' shortcomings. When teaching the Dharma to others, think to harmonize with the principles of discussion. When seeing disputes, speak both sides and reconcile them well.
When a person is in the world, an axe is in their mouth. The reason for cutting their own body is due to their evil words.
Those who are not careful with their words are not novice monks.
The precepts of novice monks state that for one's entire life one should not drink alcohol.
One should not taste alcohol, smell alcohol, or have alcoholic beverages. One should not give alcohol to others, drink medicinal alcohol, or stay in alcohol shops.
Alcohol is poisonous water, the source of many faults, which ruins the wise, destroys the sages, and invites misfortune and disaster.
It withers the four kinds of kindness and leads one away from blessings to wrongdoing.
One would rather drink molten copper than violate the prohibition against alcohol.
Those who violate this precept are not novice monks.

The precepts of novice monks state that for one's entire life one should not play with weapons, hold sharp implements, raise livestock, cage flying birds, ride in carriages and on horseback for pleasure, or go hunting and shooting at animals.

One should not set fires to burn mountains and forests, harming living beings. One should not break through lakes and ponds, or block canals and ditches. One should not use hooks to fish or nets to harm aquatic creatures.
If one violates this precept, one is no longer a novice monk.

The precepts of a novice monk are that for one's whole life one should not engage in playing chess, checkers, go, or other gambling games, arguing and competing, dancing, joking, reciting poetry, singing, playing musical instruments such as the zither, harp, koto, flute, sheng, or dizi, which disturb the mind of the Way.

One should not dig up mountains and marshes, plow fields and acres, tend to gardens and orchards, plant the five grains, engage in business with boats and carts, or compete with the people for profit.
If one violates this precept, one is no longer a novice monk.

The precepts of a novice monk are that for one's whole life one should not study strange skills, witchcraft, medicine, or sorcery, divination based on time and day, fortune-telling about good and bad omens, observing the calendar to predict prosperity and decline, eclipses of the sun and moon, strange occurrences of the stars, landslides, earthquakes, wind, rain, drought, flood, good harvests, or epidemics, and one should not know anything about them.
One should not discuss state affairs, evaluate pros and cons, or talk about military campaigns and victories.
If one violates this precept, one is no longer a novice monk.
The precepts of a novice monk are to be observed for life. Men and women have different residences and do not live in the same temple. Their tracks do not cross.
Do not ride in the same boat or carriage, or talk on the road. If they hold different things, do not look at them. Avoid suspicion from afar.
Do not exchange letters, borrow, cut, wash, or mend each other's clothes, or beg for things.
If they give to you, you should not accept.
If you want to go somewhere, you must go with an elder. Do not go alone, and do not stop to sit or stay overnight.
If one violates this precept, one is no longer a novice monk.
The precepts of a novice monk are to be observed for life. Do not befriend the unvirtuous, do not follow the unholy.

Do not associate with unfilial sons, butchers, hunters, thieves, or those who indulge in alcohol, have deviant aspirations, or engage in violent and dangerous conduct, as such associations will corrupt and undermine the practice of the Way.
The Dharma robes and alms bowl should always be with the body, not eating at improper times, and not speaking non-Dharma.
When eating, do not speak; when lying down, do not talk.
Strive to contemplate the meaning, and know the new by reviewing the old.
When sitting, meditate; when standing, recite.
If one's conduct in observing the precepts is like this, one is a true disciple of the Buddha.
After reciting the precepts, the proper conduct is explained: Having received the ten precepts of a novice monk, one becomes a virtuous practitioner of the Way.

Next, teach them to gradually start from small things. They should know the proper conduct and practice of deportment, know the age of the preceptor and the names of the three teachers, be taught to recognize the year, month, and day of first receiving the precepts, know the number of duties to serve the preceptor, also know the number of duties to serve the ÄcÄrya, also know the number of duties to offer willow branches and wash water, also know the number of duties to give the kÄá¹£Äya robe, receive the kÄá¹£Äya robe, and hold the alms bowl, also know the number of duties to hold the tin staff and carry shoes.

When together with the preceptor and master, one should know how many things there are when invited, when going to the king's house, when going to the house of a wealthy man, when going to a Brahmin's house, when eating together, when eating separately, when entering the city together to beg for food, when returning together, when arriving at the original place, when it is late in the day, when eating by the water's edge, when on the road, when eating under a tree, when going first and waiting for each other, when eating from combined bowls, when exchanging bowls, when eating facing each other, when eating before and after, when rinsing after eating, and when washing the bowls and leaving.
One should know how many things there are when serving the Sangha as a paid attendant.
When one who is twenty years old wishes to receive the full precepts, one should know all of them.
If asked by a wise bhiká¹£u and unable to respond fully, one should not be granted the upasampadÄ ordination.
Why is this?
As a novice, one does not yet know the duties to be performed, and the duties of a Å›ramaá¹‡a are difficult to carry out and extremely subtle.
Wise novice, you should go and study thoroughly.
You should fully understand and then be granted the upasampadÄ ordination.

The reason you do not know the novice precepts is simply because you have not yet fully understood the suffering of the body and have not yet subdued the mind, yet you want to receive the upasampadÄ ordination.

If the upasampadÄ ordination is granted to you now, people will say that the Buddha's teachings are easy to practice and that becoming a Å›ramaá¹‡a is easy, not knowing that the Buddha's path is supremely subtle, and that the workings of blessings and offenses, the Dharma and Vinaya, are mutually dependent. For this reason, you should be examined for several days. Therefore, you should first be asked.
If one is able to respond fully and in accordance with the Dharma, then the three teachers will be easily obtained.
There are five things the teacher teaches the novice:
First, one should respect the great Å›ramaá¹‡as;
Second, one should not call a great bhiká¹£u by name;
Third, when a great bhiká¹£u is reciting the precepts, one should not eavesdrop;
Fourth, one should not seek the faults of a great bhiká¹£u;
Fifth, when a great bhiká¹£u makes a mistake, one should not spread it around.
These are the deportment of a novice monk.
Moreover, teaching a novice monk has five things:
First, one should not scold a great bhiká¹£u in private;
Second, one should not slight a great bhiká¹£u, nor joke or imitate their speech, appearance, or gait in front of them;
Third, upon seeing a great bhiká¹£u passing by, one should immediately stand up, whether reading or reciting sÅ«tras;
If one is eating or doing various tasks, one should not get up.
Fourth, when walking and encountering a great bhiká¹£u, one should step off the path to make way for them;
Fifth, if one is joking and sees a great bhiká¹£u, one should immediately stop and apologize, saying it was not intentional.
This is how one should act.
There are ten things for a novice to do when serving the preceptor:
First, one should get up early;
Second, when entering the room, one should first snap one's fingers three times;
Third, prepare the tooth cleaner and washing water;
Fourth, offer the kaá¹£Äya robe and then offer the sandals;
Fifth, sweep the floor and add washing water;
Sixth, fold the bedding, pillow, and wipe the bed and seat;
Seventh, when the teacher has gone out and has not returned, one should not leave the room, and when the teacher returns, one should take back the kaá¹£Äya robe and fold it;
Eighth, if there is a transgression, the preceptor or ÄcÄrya instructs and admonishes, one should not speak back;
Ninth, one should lower one's head, receive the teacher's words, and think about practicing them;
Tenth, when leaving the room, one should pull the door closed.
This is the method for serving the preceptor.
There are five things for teaching a novice to serve the ÄcÄrya:
First, look at the ÄcÄrya as if looking at me;
Second, do not be frivolous;
Third, even if he scolds you, do not respond in kind;
Fourth, if he has you dispose of unclean vessels, do not spit or be angry;
Fifth, in the evening, you should massage him.
These are the rules for serving the preceptor.
The rules for serving the preceptor, the novice monk serving the master, should rise early and prepare the tooth stick and washing water.
There are six things:
First, when cutting the tooth stick, it should be according to the proper length;
Second, the tip should be broken;
Third, it should be washed to make it clean;
Fourth, the old water should be changed;
Fifth, the water jar should be cleaned;
Sixth, the water should be filled and brought in without making any splashing sound.
This is the rule for preparing the tooth stick and washing water.
There are four things when bestowing the kÄá¹£Äya robe:
First, slowly push it down with one hand and hold it with the other hand to pass it to them;
Second, look up and down in order;
Third, stop and hold the master's robe;
Fourth, it should be placed on the teacher's shoulder.
This is the method for bestowing the kÄá¹£Äya robe.
There are four things to keep in mind when putting on the kÄá¹£Äya robe:
First, one should look up and down;
Second, one should not let it touch the ground;
Third, one should put it in its usual place;
Fourth, cover it on top.
This is the method for putting on the kÄá¹£Äya robe.
There are four things to keep in mind when carrying the alms bowl:
First, one should wash it to make it clean;
Second, one should wipe it to make it dry;
Third, one should fasten the carrying strap;
Fourth, one should not make any noise.
This is the method for carrying the alms bowl.
There are four things to keep in mind when carrying the khakkhara staff:
First, one should wipe it to remove any dirt;
Second, one should not let it touch the ground and make a sound;
Third, one should offer it when the teacher comes out of the room;
Fourth, one should take it back when the teacher comes out.
If one is walking together or entering the assembly or paying homage to the Buddha, one should also take and carry it.
This is the method for carrying the khakkhara staff.
There are four things to keep in mind when carrying shoes:
First, shake it out;
Second, arrange it in order;
Third, wash your hands and do not hold the kaá¹£Äya immediately;
Fourth, when the teacher is sitting, take it and arrange it in order.
This is the method of holding the sandals.
If you are invited together and sit side by side to eat, there are four things:
First, when sitting, you should be six feet away from the teacher;
Second, you should wait until the teacher has finished the dÄna and then offer the bowl;
Third, do not eat before the teacher;
Fourth, when the teacher has finished eating, you should get up and take the bowl to be near him.
This is the method for sitting side by side to eat.
When eating separately, there are four things:
First, stand by the teacher's side;
Second, when the teacher tells you to go eat, then go and sit;
Third, bow your head to the ground in reverence;
Fourth, do not sit arrogantly and play while eating.
After eating, go to stand by the teacher's side. When the teacher tells you to return to your seat, then sit.
These are the rules for eating separately while sitting apart.
When entering the city to beg for food, there are four things:
First, one should hold the master's alms bowl;
Second, one should follow behind the master, not stepping on the master's shadow;
Third, outside the city, one should take the alms bowl and offer it to the master;
Fourth, if one wishes to go separately in the city, one should inform the master.
These are the rules for going to beg for food.
When returning together to the original place, there are four things:
First, one should slowly open the door, take out the sitting mat and spread it out;
Second, after washing the master's hands, one should then wash one's own;
Third, one should offer the alms bowl to the master and then stand with palms joined;
Fourth, one should prepare bean dregs, hand towel, and so forth in advance.
These are the rules for returning and eating.
When eating by the water's edge, there are four things:
First, one should seek a clean place;
Second, one should seek grass to sit on;
Third, after taking water to wash the teacher's hands, wash one's own hands and then return to offer the teacher's bowl;
Fourth, when the teacher instructs one to eat, one should bow and sit back.
These are the rules for eating by the waterside.
The rules for eating under a shady tree are as follows: there are four things:
First, one should carry the bowl and hang it on a tree, pick leaves to make a seat;
Second, take water to wash the teacher's hands, if water cannot be obtained, take clean grass and offer it to the teacher;
Third, take back the bowl and offer it to the teacher;
Fourth, take clean grass to wash the teacher's bowl in advance, then wipe the bowl with grass and remove it.
These are the rules for eating under a tree.
There are three things when waiting for each other on the road:
First, place the bowl on a clean place, bow according to the circumstances and speak;
Second, look at the sun to see if it is early or late, whether to return quickly or stop on the road;
Third, take the teacher's bowl and carry it, following the teacher behind.
This is the Dharma of the time of waiting in the Way.
There are two things when combining the bowls and rice:
First, if there is no curd, ghee, or porridge in the master's bowl, one should take the bowl of rice one has obtained and offer it to the master;
If the master does not take it, one should then step back.
Second, slowly take half of the rice from the master's bowl, put it on a clean place or tree leaf, step back, and take half of the rice from one's own bowl and put it in the master's bowl.
This is the Dharma of combining the bowls and rice.
There are three things when exchanging the bowls and rice:
First, if the master's bowl obtains delicious food, and one's own is not as good, one should offer it to the master;
Second, if the master wishes to exchange bowls, one should yield and not accept;
Third, if the master firmly calls to exchange bowls, one should take the leftovers and wipe the bowl to return it to the master.
This is the Dharma of exchanging the bowls and rice.
There are three things when facing the rice:
First, one should offer the bowl to the master and then sit back to eat;
Second, one should frequently observe what the teacher wishes to obtain and immediately get up to take it and give it to him.
Third, one should not eat too quickly or too slowly, and when finished, one should get up and ask again what is needed.
When the teacher says to take it away, one should then take it away.
This is the rule for facing the meal.
There are three things to do before and after the meal:
First, after presenting the teacher's bowl, one should step back and stand in a secluded place, and listen for the teacher's call to respond immediately.
Second, one should prepare washing water and place it to one side in advance.
Third, when the teacher has finished eating, one should wash the teacher's hands and stand back;
when the teacher instructs to leave the meal, one should then bow and leave the meal.
This is the rule for before and after the meal.
There are three things to do after the meal and washing the bowl:
First, after washing and rinsing, one should first take the teacher's bowl, wash it clean, and place it on a leaf;
Second, after washing one's own bowl, also place it on a tree leaf. First, take the teacher's bowl and wipe it clean and dry, put it in a bag and give it to the teacher;
Third, take one's own bowl, wipe it dry, also put it in a bag, and carry it back to the dwelling place.
This is the method for washing the bowl.
There are three things to do when leaving after washing the bowl:
First, the teacher says:
'I now wish to pass by such-and-such, Venerable So-and-so, you may return first.'
Second, bow one's head to the ground and leave;
Third, return alone, do not pass through other villages to play and laugh, but return to the original place to recite the sutra.
This is the method for leaving after washing the bowl.
There are five things for a novice to enter the assembly:
First, one should study diligently;
Second, one should practice the duties;
Third, one should serve the assembly;
Fourth, one should distribute the requisites to the fully ordained monks;
Fifth, when one wishes to receive full ordination, it is easy to obtain the three teachers.
There are five more things:
First, you should pay homage to the Buddha;
Second, you should pay homage to the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha;
Third, you should greet the monks above and below you;
Fourth, you should leave the seat for senior monks;
Fifth, you should not dispute over seating.
There are five more things:
First, you should not call out to each other or laugh while sitting;
Second, you should not get up frequently;
Third, if the assembly calls out to a certain novice, you should get up and respond;
Fourth, you should follow the orders of the saá¹…gha;
Fifth, if the monastery superintendent calls you to do something, you should return and inform your teacher.
These are called the rules for entering the assembly.
When a novice is on duty, there are five things:
First, you should be frugal with the saá¹…gha's possessions;
Second, you should not do things in the middle of the road;
Third, if you are doing something, you should not get up and leave in the middle;
Fourth, if your preceptor or teacher calls you, you should not go immediately, but should inform the monastery superintendent;
Fifth, one should follow the instructions of the monastery superintendent and not disobey.
These are the rules for being the day's attendant.
There are five things to keep in mind when selecting vegetables:
First, cut off the roots;
Second, cut them to the same length;
Third, do not mix the green and yellow ones;
Fourth, when washing the vegetables, change the water three times to make them clean, then shake them three times to remove the water;
Fifth, after finishing the work, sweep the place to make it clean.
There are five more things:
First, do not privately take the Sangha's things;
Second, if you want to take something, report it to the monastery superintendent;
Third, do your utmost to do the Sangha's work;ğŸ”½Fourth, sweep the dining hall, then put out the mats and empty the trays;
Fifth, sweep the area behind the monastery in the morning and evening, replenish the water, and discard the ashes and soil.
There are ten things to keep in mind when drawing water:
First, if your hands are dirty, do not use them to draw water. You should first wash your hands;
Second, one should not throw the bucket into the well with a loud sound.
Third, one should lower the bucket slowly, not shaking it or making a sound by hitting the sides.
Fourth, one should not let the rope's end return to the well and make a sound.
Fifth, one should not cover the well railing with shoes.
Sixth, one should not put water from the bucket directly into the cauldron.
Seventh, one should not place the bucket on the ground.
Eighth, one should wash the bathing implements to make them clean.
Ninth, when carrying water in, one should walk slowly.
Tenth, one should place it in a secluded place, not obstructing people's paths.
There are five things to do when washing the cauldron:ğŸ”½First, one should wash the rim of the cauldron above;
Second, one should wash the rim of the cauldron inside;
Third, one should wash the waist and belly;
Fourth, one should wash the inside and bottom;
Fifth, one should change the water three times.
There are five things to do when blowing on the stove:ğŸ”½First, one should not squat and blow on the fire;
Second, one should not burn fresh firewood;
Third, one should not burn wet firewood upside down;ğŸ”½Fourth, one should not burn rotten firewood;
Fifth, one should not extinguish the fire with hot water.
There are five things when sweeping the ground:
First, one should sweep in the direction of the sun;
Second, when sprinkling the ground, one should not make it too thick or too thin;
Third, one should not splash the four walls;
Fourth, one should not step on the wet ground and damage it;
Fifth, after sweeping, one should immediately gather the grass and dung and discard it.
When the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha is having a meal, there are five things for the Å›rÄmaá¹‡era to sweep the ground:
First, always sweep in the direction of the sun;
Second, one should not hold it with one hand;
Third, do not make piles of dirt more than six people high;
Fourth, sweep it all thoroughly;
Fifth, immediately sweep it up with one's own hands and carry it out to discard it.
When holding a water-filled basin to pour water, there are five things:
First, hold the top with one hand and the bottom with the other, do not switch hands.
Second, you should stand to the left side, hold it firmly, and look straight ahead.
Third, you should look at the person's hand as you pour the water, not too much or too little, directly into the person's hand.
Fourth, when pouring the water, it should be four inches away from the person's hand, neither too high nor too low, and you should watch the amount of water;
If there is not enough water for one person, you should add water, but do not stop the person's hand.
Fifth, after washing your hands, put on the kaá¹£Äya as prescribed.
There are five things to keep in mind when holding a basin:
First, do not drag the basin to make a sound;
Second, you should hold it firmly with both hands to the left;
Third, you should follow the person's hand, high or low, and do not look around;
Fourth, when the basin is full of water, you should take it out and discard it, and do not pour it on the ground in front of the person;
Fifth, after washing your hands, put on the kaá¹£Äya as prescribed.
There are five things to keep in mind when holding a towel:
First, hold the lower end with the left hand and the upper end with the right hand when handing it to others;
Second, sit two feet away, do not lean on others' laps;
Third, hold the towel, do not cover the mouth while speaking;
Fourth, do not pull away the towel while others are wiping their hands, after finishing, hold it and return it to the owner or put it back in its original place;
Fifth, wash the hands and put on the kasaya robe as prescribed.
There are five things to do when putting on sandals:
First, shake them out to remove any contents;
Second, stand up from the upper seat;
Third, show them to the master after the washing basin to let them recognize them themselves;
Fourth, do not put the left one on the right, always lower the mind to the novice monks;
Fifth, after finishing, return to wash the hands and put on the kasaya robe as prescribed.
There are seven things to do when a novice monk washes his bowl:
First, if there is leftover rice in the bowl, do not immediately discard it;
Second, if you want to discard the rice, put it on a clean place;
Third, use bean dregs or grass leaves;
Fourth, do not wash the bowl on a clean ground or in the middle of the road;
Fifth, when washing the bowl, make sure there is a stand underneath;
Sixth, add more clean water, do not discard dirty water that has washed food on the ground, so as not to pollute it;
Seventh, when wanting to discard water from the bowl, pour it four inches away from the ground, do not let it be too high or too low.
There are five things to do when wiping the bowl:
First, wash your hands again and wipe them dry;
Second, take a clean towel and place it on your lap;
Third, wipe the inside and make it dry;
Fourth, after wiping the outside with your hand, do not wipe the inside again;
Fifth, when the bowl is dry, immediately cover it with a clean towel, place it in a bag, and put it back in its usual place.
When going to a gathering meal and instructing the novice to carry the bowl, there are five things:
First, do not place it on the ground;
Second, do not stack it making a sound;
Third, do not put a tooth cleaner in the bowl;
Fourth, when someone comes to offer food, do not lean the bowl on the person's table;

Fifth, do not follow behind others offering bowls, but should go straight in front, and also not walk in the crowd. When seeing that the teacher has finished eating, then stand up, take the bowl back, and sit down.
This is the method of holding the bowl.
When sent by the teacher to express gratitude to others, there are seven things:
First, go straight;
Second, return straight;
Third, remember what the teacher said and also remember what others say in reply;
Fourth, do not pass by anything without reason;
Fifth, if asked to stay overnight, do not stop;
Sixth, do not be frivolous;
Seventh, when going out, there should be rules.
A novice monk who is serving the monks and has not finished his duties, should not enter the room of a great monk without reason.
There are three things that allow entry:
First, if the preceptor or teacher temporarily sends one to go;
Second, if asked to take something;
Third, if one wishes to go and ask about the scriptures, one should be allowed to enter.
There are seven things to do when entering a door:
First, one should snap one's fingers three times before entering;
Second, one should not stand or sit in the way, blocking the light;
Third, one should not speak of other people's affairs falsely;
Fourth, one should cross one's hands and speak in accordance with the Dharma;
Fifth, if one is told to sit, one should not cross one's legs;
Sixth, one should not be frivolous;
Seventh, one should not block others. If one wishes to leave the door, one should face the door when turning around and walk backwards out, not leaving with one's back to the door.
When sending a novice monk far away on a journey alone, one should teach him the following three things:
First, if someone asks you, 'What is your preceptor's name?' you should reply, 'His name is so-and-so.'
Second, they may ask again, 'How many years has your preceptor been a monk?' you should reply, 'He has been a monk for so many years.'
Third, they may ask again, 'Where is your preceptor from?' you should reply, 'He is from such and such a prefecture.'
If they ask you again, 'What is the name of your Ä€cÄrya?', you should reply, 'His name is so-and-so.'
If they ask you again, 'How old is your Ä€cÄrya?', you should reply, 'He is so many years old.'
If they ask you again, 'Where is your Ä€cÄrya from?', you should reply, 'He is from such-and-such a country and prefecture.'
If they ask you again, 'What is the name of the virtuous one?', you should reply, 'His name is so-and-so.'
If they ask you again, 'How long have you been a novice?', you should reply, 'For so many years, so many months, so many days, and so many hours.'
This is knowing the UpÄdhyÄya and Ä€cÄrya and also knowing the time, name, and age by year, month, and day.
There are five things when entering the bathhouse:
First, enter with your head down;
Second, when entering, avoid the place of the senior monk;
Third, when the senior monk is reading the sÅ«tra, do not speak recklessly;
Fourth, do not pour water on each other;
Fifth, do not pour water on the fire to extinguish it.
There are five more things:
First, do not be frivolous;
Second, do not break the basin or jar;
Third, do not waste too much water;
Fourth, do not use soap or sesame oil in the water;
Fifth, leave quickly and do not stop to wash clothes in the middle.
There are ten things to do when a novice goes to the back of the house:
First, if you need to defecate or urinate, go immediately;
Second, do not look around while walking;
Third, when arriving, snap your fingers three times;
Fourth, do not force others to leave;
Fifth, when arriving, snap your fingers three times again;
Sixth, do not swallow loudly;
Seventh, do not lower your head to look at the genitals;
Eighth, do not play with the ash on top;
Ninth, do not pour water on the walls;
Tenth, after returning, wash your hands. Do not touch things without washing your hands.
There are five more things:
First, do not spit directly on the front wall;
Second, do not look around to the left and right;
Third, do not use grass to draw on walls or the ground;
Fourth, do not use fire sticks to draw on the ground or walls;
Fifth, do not stay in the latrine for too long.
You should leave on your own. If you encounter someone, do not bow to them, but should avoid the path and go around.
Having finished speaking the rules of deportment for novice monks,
The seventy-two rules of deportment for novice monks have a total of fourteen matters.
The teacher speaks to you:
There are two matters:
First, do not respond in words;
Second, do not reason with yourself.
There are ten matters for a novice monk to bow to the teacher:
First, if there is a bowl in front of the teacher's head, do not bow;ğŸ”½Second, if the teacher is sitting in meditation, do not bow;
Third, if the teacher is walking, do not bow;
Fourth, if the teacher is eating, do not bow;
Fifth, if the teacher is expounding the sÅ«tras, do not bow;
Sixth, when meeting the teacher, do not bow with the left side;
Seventh, when the teacher is combing his teeth, do not bow;
Eighth, when wanting to enter the door to bow, snap your fingers three times. If the teacher does not respond, leave;
Ninth, do not leave the teacher more than seven steps;
Tenth, when the teacher's door opens, bow.
There are five things to do when getting up early and entering the room:
First, tidy up the bedding;
Second, take out the bowl;
Third, sweep the floor;
Fourth, ask about the sÅ«tras;
Fifth, offer things.
There are five things to do when folding the three robes:

Third, know the inside and outside of the robes;
Fourth, do not fold them upside down;
Fifth, put them in the usual place.
There are five things to do when following the teacher:ğŸ”½First, do not pass by people's houses;
Second, do not stop on the road to talk with people;
Third, do not look around to the left and right;
Fourth, lower your head and follow the teacher behind;
Fifth, when arriving at the donor's house, stand to one side. If the teacher instructs you to sit,
There are five things to provide for the teacher:ğŸ”½First, you should obtain a willow branch;
Second, you should obtain bath beans;

There are five things to consider when washing as a novice monk:
First, do not face the pagoda;ğŸ”½Second, do not face the preceptor;
Third, do not face the instructor;
Fourth, do it in a secluded place;
Fifth, take the water yourself, do not use the water used by others for other purposes.
There are five things to do when entering the room in the evening:
First, sweep the bed;
Second, arrange the bedding;
Third, put away the bowl;
Fourth, light the lamp;
Fifth, if instructed to sleep, leave.
When leaving, one should pull the door closed with one's back to it.
There are five things for a novice to receive the sÅ«tras from the teacher:
First, arrange the robes;
Second, join palms and bow;
Third, do not step back;
Fourth, the two feet should be even;
Fifth, slightly bend.
There are five things for a novice to give the three robes to the teacher:
First, wash the hands;ğŸ”½Second, give the aná¸avÄsa;
Third, give the uttarÄsaá¹…ga;
Fourth, give the saá¹…ghÄá¹­Ä«;

There are five things for a novice to wash the alms bowl:
First, get cow dung ash;
Second, get soap beans;
Third, be seven inches off the ground;
Fourth, do not make noise, change the water three times, do not sprinkle water on the ground when discarding water;
Fifth, let it dry.
There are five things for a novice to sweep the ground:
First, do not turn your back on the teacher;
Second, do not sweep against the grain;
Third, make sure it is clean;
Fourth, do not leave any traces;
Fifth, discard it immediately.
There are five things a novice monk should do when following his teacher to a layperson's home:ğŸ”½First, hold the alms bowl;
Second, hold a towel;
Third, knock on the door;
Fourth, when arriving at the layperson's home, ask for clean water to wash the bowl;
Fifth, when the teacher sits, take the towel and bowl and offer them to the teacher, then sit down yourself.
There are five things to do when a novice monk enters the bathhouse:
First, do not enter before the teacher;
Second, do not sit in front of the teacher;
Third, do not move if the teacher has not yet obtained water;
Fourth, if you wish to massage the back, first inform the teacher;
Fifth, after bathing, first take the robe to put on.
There are thirteen things to do regarding the novice monk's etiquette and deportment, as well as the morning and evening greetings and reverence:
First, get up early and wash;
Second, one should arrange one's robes;
Third, one should inquire about one's well-being;
Fourth, if the teacher is inside and one wishes to approach, one should first remove the things worn on the head and feet;
Fifth, one should not step on the teacher's shadow;
Sixth, one should stand outside, snap one's fingers three times, call out, and then enter;
Seventh, one should touch one's forehead to the ground and bow in respect;
Eighth, if ordered to sit, one should sit after three refusals;
Ninth, one's sitting must be dignified;
Tenth, if asked a question, one should respond clearly and distinctly;
Eleventh, if one has nothing to say, one should remain silent;ğŸ”½Twelfth, if one must withdraw, one should bow as before;
Thirteenth, when wishing to leave the room, one should turn one's body back to the direction one came from.
When a novice attendant holds the teacher's washbasin, there are fifteen rules:
First, one should clean the washbasin;
Second, it should have a fixed place;
Third, it should be filled with clean water;
Fourth, do not use water that has been left overnight;
Fifth, prepare toothpicks in advance;
Sixth, when cleaning the toothpicks, make sure they are in accordance with the rules;
Seventh, the washbasin should be one foot away from the knees;
Eighth, when holding the washbasin, hold the top with the left hand and the bottom with the right hand;
Ninth, pour out the water appropriately, making sure to get the right amount;
Tenth, do not make any noise;
Eleventh, the towel should always be in a fixed place;
Twelfth, when holding the towel, hold the towel with the left hand and offer it to the teacher with the right hand;
Thirteenth, when discarding the dirty water, there should always be a fixed place;
Fourteenth, do not splash the clean ground;
Fifteenth, after using the towel, it should be returned to its usual place.
There are also eight things to keep in mind when sprinkling, sweeping, dusting, and arranging the bed:
First, always face the honored ones;
Second, do not turn your back;ğŸ”½Third, when sprinkling the ground, use a light hand and control the amount of water;
Fourth, when using a broom, face it yourself;
Fifth, the excrement should always be in a fixed place;
Sixth, sweep and wipe the bed and seat;
Seventh, fold the bedding and pillow;
Eighth, sweep and wipe the bed without making noise.
Moreover, there are fourteen things to keep in mind when serving the teacher's food:
First, one should be equipped with a clean towel;
Second, when serving food, one should hold the bowl with both hands;
Third, one should serve directly;
Fourth, kneel and offer to the teacher;
Fifth, do not speak or laugh with people on the way;
Sixth, when serving food, do not make any noise;
Seventh, the food and drink served should be of appropriate temperature;
Eighth, the spoon and chopsticks should be kept clean;
Ninth, if there is anything to be added, it must be balanced;
Tenth, one should always stay in a fixed place;
Eleventh, one should be dignified;
Twelfth, when the meal is finished and the utensils are to be collected, one should do so slowly;
Thirteenth, collect them in the order they were used;
Fourteenth, wash the utensils as usual.
There are ten more rules for taking the Dharma robes and shoes:
First, hold the top with the left hand and the bottom with the right hand;
Second, kneel and offer them to the teacher;
Third, fold the kaá¹£Äya, do not bite it with your mouth;
Fourth, do not shake it to make a sound;
Fifth, return it to its usual place;
Sixth, cover it with a cloth;
Seventh, when taking the shoes, shake them first;
Eighth, do not make a loud noise;
Ninth, when placing them on the ground, make them neat and proper;
Tenth, return them to their usual place.
If taking the alms bowl and water bottle, there are eight rules:
First, wipe them clean first;
Second, support the bottom with both hands;
Third, kneel and take the teacher's bowl;
Fourth, when washing, use soap nuts and bean dregs;
Fifth, make sure they are dry in the hands;
Sixth, if there is an urgent matter to attend to, place them in the sun;
Seventh, if it is wet, dry it by the fire;
Eighth, return it to its original place.
If you take the tin staff, there are seven things:
First, sweep and wipe it clean;
Second, do not place it on the ground;
Third, do not point it at anything;
Fourth, do not make any noise;
Fifth, hold it with both hands;
Sixth, kneel and offer it to the teacher;
Seventh, return it to its original place.
Also, when serving the teacher in bathing and shaving, and in the morning wearing the Dharma robes, there are twelve things:
First, be respectful and do what is appropriate;
Second, adjust to the temperature;
Third, sweep the bathhouse;
Fourth, prepare clean water;
Fifth, first prepare soap nuts, bath powder, and sesame oil;
Sixth, take a clean towel in advance;
Seventh, prepare a stove and fire for cold weather;
Eighth, stand outside the door and do not let anyone enter;
Ninth, when removing hair, it must be done in a regular place;
Tenth, when drying Dharma robes, one must wait until they are completely dry;
Eleventh, when going out on urgent business, one must entrust [the duties] to someone else, not forgetting to leave;
Twelfth, when taking on duties, one must return them to their usual place.
There are seven things to keep in mind when handling incense and flowers:
First, one should wipe the incense burner clean;
Second, one should remove the old flowers;
Third, one should adjust the amount of firewood;
Fourth, when offering incense and flowers, one should start from the highest seat;
Fifth, when offering incense, one's hands should be five inches apart;
Sixth, when holding the incense burner, one should not let the smoke drift towards oneself;
Seventh, one should finally place [the incense and flowers] in their usual place.
There are eight things to keep in mind when lighting lamps:
First, remove the old wicks;
Second, wash and clean the lamp bowls;
Third, adjust the amount of oil;
Fourth, seek clean wicks;
Fifth, do not let them burn out, but go and add oil frequently;
Sixth, in the morning, get up early and inspect the protection;
Seventh, when the oil is not yet exhausted, support the remaining wick and gather it in a leaning place, and burn it separately until it is exhausted;
Eighth, finally, slowly return it to its original place.
If you go to pick flowers or get willow branches, there are nine things:
First, if there is an owner, ask the owner;
Second, if there is no owner, you should chant a spell for the mountain, marsh, and tree spirits;
Third, when taking flowers and willow branches, do not pull up the roots;
Fourth, on the road, go straight back and forth;
Fifth, do not be lazy or speak playfully;
Sixth, if you are violated by others, be careful not to associate with people;
Seventh, lower your head and inwardly reproach yourself, do not let there be a hateful mind;
Eighth, if you want to offer flowers, start with the upper seat;
Ninth, you should remove the withered flowers.
In all practices, do not act on your own, there are eighteen things:
First, when going out or coming in, you should first inform your teacher;

Second, if you wish to practice overnight, you should first inform your teacher;ğŸ”½Third, if you wish to make new Dharma robes, you should first inform your teacher;ğŸ”½Fourth, if you wish to wear new Dharma robes, you should first inform your teacher and receive them from him;
Fifth, if you wish to wash Dharma robes, you should first inform your teacher;
Sixth, if you wish to shave your head, you should first inform your teacher;
Seventh, if you are sick and taking medicine, you should first inform your teacher;

Eighth, if you are doing work for the Sangha, you should first inform your teacher and leave;ğŸ”½Ninth, if you wish to have paper and writing implements privately, you should first inform your teacher;

Tenth, if you wish to chant sutras and hymns, you should first inform your teacher;ğŸ”½Eleventh, if someone gives you a gift, you should first inform your teacher before accepting it;ğŸ”½Twelfth, if you wish to give your own belongings to others, you should first inform your teacher, and only give them after your teacher has agreed;
Thirteenth, if someone borrows something from you, you should first inform your teacher, and only lend it to them after your teacher has agreed;
Fourteenth, if one wishes to borrow something from others, one should inform the teacher and only go with permission;
Fifteenth, the manner of informing is to first adjust one's clothes and bow in reverence;
Sixteenth, whether one is permitted or not, one should be respectful and bow in reverence;
Seventeenth, state what one wishes to know;
Eighteenth, do not have resentment or speak with a negative attitude.
Furthermore, there are sixteen matters for going out and returning before and after the teacher:
First, one should adjust one's clothes;
Second, know the direction of speech and always respond accordingly, following those who carry the staff and towel;
Third, follow behind the teacher;
Fourth, do not step on his shadow;
Fifth, do not playfully wave the staff in front of him;
Sixth, do not speak with people on the road;
Seventh, do not speak ill of the teacher or his faults;
Eighth, if the teacher sends one back to get something, one should follow the way one came;
Ninth, one should immediately act according to his instructions;
Tenth, do not linger.
Eleventh, if the teacher instructs you to stay and speak the sutra for the patron, you should immediately bow and follow the instructions;
Twelfth, return early in the evening;
Thirteenth, do not stay overnight;
Fourteenth, when returning to the invitation, first adjust your robes;
Fifteenth, you should prostrate with your whole body and pay homage;
Sixteenth, pay homage to the teacher as usual.
If you go alone to send off the dead or inquire about illnesses, there are nine things:
First, at the host's door, you should know the proper etiquette for advancing and retreating. If there is a separate seat, you should sit. If there is no separate seat, you should not sit mixed in.
Second, you should look at the seats. If there are taboos, sit upright.
Third, if people want to ask about the sutra, you should know the right time.
Fourth, do not speak at the wrong time.
Fifth, even if the host offers food outside of the proper time, do not lose the proper etiquette.
Sixth, it is appropriate to return by the day;
Seventh, do not violate the rule of not traveling at night;
Eighth, if it is late in the evening with strong winds and rain, make a decision according to the circumstances;
Ninth, upon returning, resume the usual routine.
If one encounters the teacher on the road, there are six things:
First, one should first adjust one's clothes;
Second, one should take off one's leather shoes;
Third, when paying respects to the teacher, one should bow one's head to the teacher's feet;
Fourth, one should follow behind the teacher;
Fifth, if the teacher goes off on his own, one should bow and accept the teacher's instructions;
Sixth, even if one does not follow the teacher, one's conduct and etiquette should always be as usual.
When the Sangha is having a meal, there are sixteen rules:
First, upon hearing the sound of the gavel, one should immediately adjust one's clothes;
Second, one should take off one's leather shoes and go to stand under the pagoda;
Third, one should stand with dignity;
Fourth, if one arrives after the teacher, one should stand in one's place and be careful not to speak or laugh;
Fifth, when a superior person recites the sÅ«tra and makes aspirations, one should all be respectful and never lose propriety;
Sixth, when about to eat, one should first look up and down;
Seventh, do not eat in front of a crowd, and do not stop eating after the crowd;
Eighth, do not criticize the good and bad of the food;
Ninth, do not eat too much or too little;
Tenth, be careful not to swallow loudly;ğŸ”½Eleventh, do not use the bowl to scrape up food;
Twelfth, do not tap the table with the bowl;
Thirteenth, do not ask for more;
Fourteenth, do not privately give food to others or pick out food to give to dogs;
Fifteenth, if someone comes to offer more food, do not say you do not need it;
Sixteenth, if you have already eaten your fill, you should politely decline with your hands.
Moreover, when the Saá¹ƒgha recites the sÅ«tra, there are thirteen matters, whether reciting the sÅ«tra at a Dharma assembly, in a warm room or a cool room, or in a bathhouse:
First, one should straighten one's clothes;
Second, one should look straight ahead and walk straight;
Third, one should not speak or laugh with people on the road;
Fourth, one should pay respects to the elders in order;
Fifth, one should sit in the seat in order when returning;
Sixth, when the elders are expounding the sutra, one should sit in one's place;
Seventh, one's sitting must be dignified;
Eighth, one should be careful not to speak recklessly;
Ninth, one should not cough or spit loudly;
Tenth, one should not spit on the clean ground, which violates the precepts;
Eleventh, if one's turn to expound the sutra has come, one should immediately do so;
Twelfth, when one is chosen by the assembly to ascend the high seat, one should first examine one's actions and be careful not to lose propriety;
Thirteenth, if there is a loss of meaning in the sitting, one should stop evil and promote goodness, and be careful not to show one's faults.
Moreover, there are thirteen things in the assembly's sutra recitation. If one's turn has come, one should recite on the appointed day, and pay respects in the morning and evening:
First, upon hearing the sound of the wooden fish, one should prepare incense and fire in advance;
Second, one should offer incense as usual;
Third, arrange the necessary items in order;
Fourth, clean the bedding and seats;
Fifth, sweep and sprinkle as prescribed;
Sixth, if there is an assembly, clearly hand over what is collected to the donors for use;
Seventh, after the matter is finished, take it back and make it as it was before;
Eighth, always make it a rule to lock the door early and open it late;
Ninth, if there are unusual guests, listen to the teacher's side and give them what they need;
Tenth, if there are guests staying, all should straighten their clothes and stay in their usual positions;
Eleventh, if there is something, respond immediately and clearly;
Twelfth, when staying, be dignified and do not lose propriety;
Thirteenth, if you want to go out for a while, have someone replace you, and do not leave the place empty for a long time.
Again, the ten matters to be known after taking charge of the day's work, if one is on duty, one should follow the rules and cultivate. There are many tasks and efforts:
First, to build a stupa;
Second, to discuss the affairs of the monks in the lecture hall;
Third, if making Buddha images, always get up early and worry about recognizing the work;
Fourth, one should select what is suitable, and use the wrong axe and saw to make sure it is always in place;
Fifth, if the painted vermilion and glue ink are obtained in advance, do not let there be a shortage at the last minute;
Sixth, it is appropriate to select and record again, and there is a constant place;
The original scriptures have seven or eight things that are received, clearly handed over without error;
Seventh, when there is something to buy and seek, ask the monastery superintendent;
Eighth, when spending, let the rest be displayed and have a basis.
Again, there are sixteen things to do when going out for alms alone:
If going out for alms, first, one should go with others;
Second, if there is no one to go with, one should know where to go;
Third, the alms bowl should always be on the left side;
Fourth, when wearing the alms bowl, when going out, it should face outward;
Fifth, when returning with food, you should face inward;
Sixth, when arriving at someone's door, you should be careful in your movements;
Seventh, if there are no men in the household, do not enter the door;
Eighth, if you wish to sit, you should first look at the seat;
Ninth, if there are knives and weapons on the seat, you should not sit;
Tenth, if there are precious objects, you should not sit;
Eleventh, if there are women's clothing, bedding, and ornaments, you should not sit; if there are none of these, then it is acceptable to sit;
Twelfth, the host provides food;
Thirteenth, after eating, you should chant a sutra;
Fourteenth, you should not ask about the quality of the food;
Fifteenth, do not recite sutras before eating;
Sixteenth, although you may wish to recite sutras, you should know the appropriate time to recite and the inappropriate time to recite.
There are also nine things to keep in mind when shopping:
First, you should lower your head and go straight, return straight;
Second, if you see strange things, do not look at them carefully;
Third, do not argue about high and low status;
Fourth, do not sit in a brothel;
Fifth, if you are offended by others, avoid it skillfully and do not seek justice;
Sixth, when buying and selling, if you have sent the money in good faith, do not say to come and take it, causing back and forth;
Seventh, if you have already promised someone something, even if it is cheaper elsewhere, do not abandon that and take this, causing the original owner to be resentful;
Eighth, if you see members of the four groups buying and selling at a low price, do not take it upon yourself, but say that it is not allowed according to the Dharma;
Ninth, be careful not to guarantee anything that leads to mistakes or debts.
There are also nine things when visiting a nunnery. If the teacher sends you to a nunnery, first, you should go with someone;
Second, circumambulate the stupa and pay homage as usual;
Third, if there are separate seats, do not sit on them if they are not for your use;
Fourth, if you have a question about the sutra due to illness, explain what is appropriate to say;
Fifth, one should not speak at inappropriate times;
Sixth, one should not point out the faults of others;
Seventh, if one is offered precious and unusual clothing, towels, or shoes, one should not accept any of them;
Eighth, one should not speak of their good or bad qualities upon returning;
Ninth, one should not say that they only make offerings to a certain person.
There are also eight things to keep in mind when lecturing on the sutras and reciting the Dharma:
First, one must be thorough and careful, as different people have different views and may have different practices;
Second, one should be cautious and not insist that one's own understanding is correct and others' is wrong;
Third, if fellow practitioners argue, one should strive to reconcile them and resolve their differences;
Fourth, when there are tasks to be done, one should not take over and show off one's own abilities;
Fifth, when the great Å›ramaá¹‡as are expounding the precepts, one should not look at them;
Sixth, if one knows that one has committed an offense against the assembly, one should immediately confess and resolve it together with the others;
Seventh, if the teacher asks:
So-and-so says you have committed an offense.
then one should follow the matter and explain it;
eighth, one should not conceal faults and create offenses.
There are ten matters in the Analects, which should be recited and practiced day and night at three times: first, to arrange one's clothes;
second, when practicing walking meditation, one must have a fixed place;
third, it should be in the middle;
fourth, in the lecture hall;
fifth, or under the pagoda;
sixth, also in the dining hall;ğŸ”½seventh, one should not wear leather shoes;
eighth, one should not wear wooden shoes;
ninth, one should not carry a staff;
tenth, one should be careful not to lie down and recite the sutra.

Moreover, there are ten matters in reciting sutras and practicing walking meditation. The constant method in the room is: first, sleeping and resting are different and do not interfere with each other;
second, receiving and reciting the sutra;
third, discussing the meaning of the sutra;
fourth, inquiring about illnesses;
fifth, or going for convenience;
sixth, one should not speak of urgent matters;
seventh, one should not point out the faults of others;
Eighth, one should not criticize each other;
Ninth, when borrowing or lending, one must be clear;
Tenth, do not violate the agreed time and lose the trust of the Way.
The Ten Precepts and Rules for Novice Monks in One Scroll The five virtues are:
First, giving rise to the aspiration to leave the secular and embrace the Way;
Second, destroying one's beautiful appearance and conforming to the Dharma robes;
Third, forever cutting off familial love and having no attachments;
Fourth, disregarding one's body and life and upholding the Way;
Fifth, aspiring to the Mahayana in order to liberate others.
The ten items are:
First, all sentient beings rely on food and drink to survive;
Second, name and form;
Third, three kinds of feelings;
Fourth, four noble truths;
Fifth, five aggregates;
Sixth, six sense bases;
Seventh, seven factors of enlightenment;
Eighth, eightfold noble path;
Ninth, nine abodes of sentient beings;
Tenth, ten universal bases.
